docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women with asthma are likely to experience worse symptoms if they are carrying a girl, a new study finds. In the past, doctors treating asthmatics who were pregnant noticed what seemed to be a link between how well their patients did and the sex of their children.

headline.main: For Asthmatic Women, Good News in Having a Boy

docs.abstract: Helen L Kwon, former Yale University researcher who is now with Columbia University, leads study on pregnant women suffering from asthma; research, which is published in American Journal of Epidemiology, finds women carrying boys experience better lung function during pregnancy than those women carrying girls; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Pregnant women with asthma are likely to experience worse symptoms if they are carrying a girl, a new study finds.     In the past, doctors treating asthmatics who were pregnant noticed what seemed to be a link between how well their patients did and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Volcano's Cold, Cold Shadow The 1883 eruption of Krakatoa in Indonesia ranks among the most powerful volcanic blasts in history. It spewed six cubic miles of ash and dirt into the air and disrupted the world's climate for several years. Krakatoa's reputation hardly needs burnishing, but Peter J. Gleckler of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and his colleagues have done so anyway. They've found that the eruption had effects on ocean temperatures and sea level that persisted for decades.
docs.abstract: Peter J Gleckler of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory leads study on impact of 1883 eruption of Krakatoa on ocean temperatures; research, which is published in journal Nature, finds that temperature of ocean was cooler and penetrated deeper than originally believed; amateur volcanologists can observe eruption of Augustine, volcano in Cook Inlet southwest of Anchorage, Alaska, over internet at www.avo.alaska.edu; Raphael Ritson-Williams of Smithsonian Marine Station, Fort Pierce, Fla, leads study on recently discovered flatworm found on Guam; research, which is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, describes flatworm's unique use of toxic chemical tetrodotoxin to kill prey; Dr Toni E Ziegler of University of Wisconsin's National Primate Research Center leads study on marmoset and tamarin behavior during pregnancy; research, which was done on males, shows that they gain weight during their mate's pregnancy; gain is apparently caused by hormonal changes; research is published in journal Biology Letters; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Volcano's Cold, Cold Shadow       The 1883 eruption of Krakatoa in Indonesia ranks among the most powerful volcanic blasts in history. It spewed six cubic miles of ash and dirt into the air and disrupted the world's climate for several years.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students work in small groups to analyze the recent rise of homicides in some American cities, create and share posters, and write reflective essays in the form of letters to community leaders.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students work in small groups to analyze the recent rise of homicides in some American cities, create and share posters, and write reflective essays in the form of letters to community leaders.

byline.original: By SIERRA PRASADA MILLMAN and YASMIN CHIN EISENHAUER

docs.lead_paragraph: Monique stands in the middle of the examination room, the white blanket wrapped around her. ''Get us out of here,'' she says to Win.

headline.main: At Risk: Chapter 6: The D.A.'s Getaway

docs.lead_paragraph: One woman here killed a friend after they argued over a brown silk dress. A man killed a neighbor whose 10-year-old son had mistakenly used his dish soap. Two men argued over a cellphone, and pulling out their guns, the police say, killed a 13-year-old girl in the crossfire. While violent crime has been at historic lows nationwide and in cities like New York, Miami and Los Angeles, it is rising sharply here and in many other places across the country.

headline.main: Violent Crime Rising Sharply In Some Cities

docs.abstract: Violent crime is at historic low in many cities, but is rising sharply in Milwaukee, Houston, Philadelphia and elsewhere; killings are often sparked by minor incident, with suspects telling police they killed someone who 'disrespected' them or gave them dirty look; suspects tend to be black, young, and have previous criminal records; police blame anger, easy access to guns, lax sentences and judges who grant bail too easily; graphs; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Police say a rise in homicides has been set off by petty disputes that hardly seem the stuff of gunfire or stabbings.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a span of less than a year, ''World News Tonight'' on ABC has had to cope with the death of one anchor (Peter Jennings) and the serious wounds sustained by another (Bob Woodruff) in Iraq. But yesterday, the program made an announcement that David Westin, the president of ABC News, characterized as ''life affirming'': Elizabeth Vargas, right, Mr. Woodruff's co-anchor since Jan. 3, is expecting her second child. The network said in a statement that Ms. Vargas, 43, and her husband, the singer Marc Cohn, 46, were expecting a baby in late summer. They also have a son, and Mr. Cohn has two children from a previous marriage. ABC said Ms. Vargas would continue to serve as a co-anchor of ''World News Tonight'' and the prime-time magazine ''20/20'' for the duration of her pregnancy. Her pregnancy and expected maternity leave have become yet another variable that the network will have to consider as it makes interim anchor assignments in Mr. Woodruff's absence. At least through the end of this month, Ms. Vargas will be joined as anchor most nights by Charles Gibson or Diane Sawyer. ''When the timetable for Woodruff's recovery becomes clearer in the coming weeks,'' the network said yesterday, ''ABC News will announce further interim plans for substitution on the broadcast.'' Mr. Woodruff, who suffered serious head injuries and other wounds in a bomb attack in Iraq last month, remains hospitalized at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. In a statement earlier this week, ABC said he was being ''sedated for now to help with the healing of his various injuries.'' JACQUES STEINBERG

headline.main: Arts, Briefly; Some Happy News for ABC

docs.abstract: ABC News president David Westin announces that Elizabeth Vargas is expecting second child but will continue as co-anchor of World News Tonight and 20/20; her pregnancy introduces yet another variable as ABC News juggles interim anchor assignments in absence of Bob Woodruff, who is recovering from injuries sustained in Iraq; Vargas photo (S)

byline.original: By JACQUES STEINBERG; Compiled by Lawrence Van Gelder

docs.lead_paragraph: The government-approved system for preventing pregnant women from taking Accutane, the acne drug linked to miscarriages and severe birth defects, is a ''disaster,'' the nation's leading dermatology association told a federal advisory panel on Friday. ''Pharmacies, prescribers and patients are confused and frustrated,'' said Dr. Diane M. Thiboutot of the American Academy of Dermatology, who held a stack of what she said were samples of 200 complaints from dermatologists. She asked the panel to delay the system's mandatory starting date of March 1 by at least two months.

headline.main: System Said to Fail to Steer Women From Acne Drug

docs.abstract: Dr Diane M Thiboutot of American Academy of Dermatology tells Food and Drug Administration advisory panel that government-approved system for preventing pregnant women from taking Accutane, acne drug linked to miscarriages and birth defects, is disaster; asks panel to delay system's mandatory starting date of March 1 by at least two months (M)
docs.snippet: A dermatology association called a disaster the government-approved system to prevent women from taking an acne drug linked to miscarriages.

docs.lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old high school senior who handed hospital workers a knapsack containing her dead newborn was charged on Thursday with second-degree manslaughter, the police said. The teenager, Zehra Catalbas of Mount Sinai, delivered the baby girl last Saturday morning alone in a shower at her home, according to Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick of the Suffolk County Police Department's homicide squad.

headline.main: High School Student Charged In Death of Newborn Daughter

docs.abstract: Mount Sinai, NY, High School senior Zehra Catalbas brings her dead, newborn baby girl to hospital in knapsack; is charged with second-degree manslaughter; Catalbas showered with baby for two hours after delivering it; authorities perform autopsy to determine exactly when and how baby died (M)
docs.snippet: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y., Feb. 10  An 18-year-old high school senior who handed hospital workers a knapsack containing her dead newborn was charged on Thursday with second-degree manslaughter, the police said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Challenging a political rival over access to abortion, Eliot Spitzer, the leading Democratic candidate for governor, vowed support yesterday for any late-term abortion to protect the health or life of the mother, and said that New York needed a leader with that commitment in case the United States Supreme Court restricted abortion. ''I want to make it clear from the start that if the new Supreme Court turns its back on women's privacy and limits or overturns Roe versus Wade, I will do everything in my power to preserve that right here in New York,'' Mr. Spitzer, the state attorney general, said in remarks at New York Law School, where he was joined by his wife, Silda, his mother, Anne, and abortion rights supporters.

headline.main: Spitzer, Seeing a Democratic Challenge, Sharpens View on Abortion

docs.abstract: Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer vows that if elected governor of New York, he will support abortion rights, including late-term abortion; takes aim at Nassau County Exec Thomas R Suozzi, rival for Democratic nomination, who supports ban on so-called partial-birth abortions without exception; Naral Pro-Choice New York endorses Spitzer; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Eliot Spitzer, the leading Democratic candidate for New York governor, took aim at possible challenger Thomas R. Suozzi over abortion views.

docs.lead_paragraph: Expectant mothers who took antidepressants like Prozac late in their pregnancy were significantly more likely to give birth to an infant with a rare but serious breathing problem, doctors are reporting today. The lung disorder, called persistent pulmonary hypertension, strikes 1 to 2 newborns in 1,000, on average, and can be fatal. In babies exposed to antidepressants during the last few months of pregnancy, the study found, the rate was six times as high: 6 to 12 newborns in 1,000.

headline.main: Antidepressants May Harm Infants' Lungs, Report Says

docs.snippet: The report sparked concerns and F.D.A. officials said they would consider whether to require manufacturers to make labeling changes.
